content.raw: Would be nice to have this element also at the model level, where the link value will be interpreted as overriding the model value.
content.html: Would be nice to have this element also at the model level, where the link value will be interpreted as overriding the model value.

content.raw: I think this could be added directly to world.sdf without being in a separate file (see pull request #247 for an example)
content.html: I think this could be added directly to world.sdf without being in a separate file (see pull request #247 for an example)

content.raw: You are right, the idea was to limit the wind to the horizontal plane. It has now been replaced by a `Vector3` as you suggested.
content.html: You are right, the idea was to limit the wind to the horizontal plane. It has now been replaced by a Vector3 as you suggested.

update.title: New <wind> element

content.html: pull request #247

content.raw: I see what you mean. I hadn't thought of physics like that. But it's true, the rest of the elements under physics seem to be all about how to solve the physics instead of world properties. I agree with you that it should be under world.
content.html: I see what you mean. I hadn't thought of physics like that. But it's true, the rest of the elements under physics seem to be all about how to solve the physics instead of world properties. I agree with you that it should be under world.
+1 for using a Vector3

content.raw:
I just noticed that `magnetic_field` is also a physics property.

As I think about it more, though, I think it makes more sense to make `gravity`, `magnetic_field`, and `wind` properties of the world, since that's what it's describing. The properties in `physics` describe numerical things like time step and update rate and also default values of physical properties.

So I would advocate leaving `wind` where it is and move `gravity` and `magnetic_field` in a separate pull request.
content.html:
I just noticed that magnetic_field is also a physics property.

As I think about it more, though, I think it makes more sense to make gravity, magnetic_field, and wind properties of the world, since that's what it's describing. The properties in physics describe numerical things like time step and update rate and also default values of physical properties.

So I would advocate leaving wind where it is and move gravity and magnetic_field in a separate pull request.

content.raw:
In the proposed implementation, the Wind instance is handled by the World instance and there is no interaction between the PhysicsEngine and the Wind instances directly. The Wind instance only interacts with physics::Entity.

The Wind instance could be moved inside the PhysicsEngine instance. This would mean that to access the Wind instance, one would have to access the PhysicsEngine instance first. And, to be consistent, the wind properties should be moved inside the physics properties in gzclient. I am not sure which solution would be preferable.
content.html:
In the proposed implementation, the Wind instance is handled by the World instance and there is no interaction between the PhysicsEngine and the Wind instances directly. The Wind instance only interacts with physics::Entity.

The Wind instance could be moved inside the PhysicsEngine instance. This would mean that to access the Wind instance, one would have to access the PhysicsEngine instance first. And, to be consistent, the wind properties should be moved inside the physics properties in gzclient. I am not sure which solution would be preferable.

update.title: New <wind> element

content.raw: A `Vector3` implementation would not require a separate magnitude element and in fact, maybe not even a `wind.sdf` (again, I'm tracing parallels to gravity and magnetic field)
content.html: A Vector3 implementation would not require a separate magnitude element and in fact, maybe not even a wind.sdf (again, I'm tracing parallels to gravity and magnetic field)

content.raw: Maybe it could go inside `physics`? I'm making a parallel with gravity and magnetic field.
content.html: Maybe it could go inside physics? I'm making a parallel with gravity and magnetic field.

content.raw:
So the wind is limited to the horizontal plane, correct? I wonder if we will want to expand this to 3D in the future. Not sure if it's a good idea to declare it as a vector3 here but only handle the horizontal component for now...?

(I'm saying this before looking at the implementation, it might not make sense to have a wind vector)
content.html:
So the wind is limited to the horizontal plane, correct? I wonder if we will want to expand this to 3D in the future. Not sure if it's a good idea to declare it as a vector3 here but only handle the horizontal component for now...?

(I'm saying this before looking at the implementation, it might not make sense to have a wind vector)

content.raw: I think this will need to be moved to `sdf/1.6`. The version has been upgraded in pull request #243
content.html: I think this will need to be moved to sdf/1.6. The version has been upgraded in pull request #243
